questions.text: A 10-month-old, exclusively breastfed infant presents with lethargy, poor feeding, restlessness, developmental delay, and abdominal distention. The mother’s diet is high in polished rice. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible?
questions.correct_answer: B. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)
questions.explanation:
Vitamin

RDA

Dietary Sources

Thiamine (B1)

0.2-0.3 mg/day

Unpolished rice, oats, legumes, wheat, meat

Cobalamin (B12)

0.3-0.5 μg / day

Milk, meat, eggs (not found in plant sources)

Folate

65-80 μg/day

Green leafy vegetables, citrus fruits, papaya

Vitamin Deficiencies
 

Thiamine Deficiency

Vit B12 Deficiency

(Option A)

Vitamin B9 (Folate) Deficiency (Option C)

Cause
  • Polished rice diet
  • Refined wheat flour diet.
  • Alcoholism
  • Malnutrition
  • Malignancies
  • Vegan diet.
  • Maternal deficiency during breastfeeding.
  • Malabsorption syndromes (e.g. Celiac disease, Crohn's disease).
  • Poor dietary intake,
  • Malabsorption (e.g., celiac disease, IBD),
  • Increased demand (e.g., sickle cell disease, malignancies)
  • Inborn errors of folate metabolism,
  • Cerebral folate deficiency

Clinical features:

Early: Lethargy, Irritability, restlessness, depression, drowsiness, poor concentration and GI discomfort.

 

Late:

Dry Beriberi (neurologic): Peripheral neuritis, decreased reflexes, loss of vibration sense, muscle tenderness, cramping, ataxia, loss of coordination

Wet Beriberi (cardiac): Heart failure, tachycardia, edema, cardiomegaly

Infantile: Emesis, lethargy, restlessness, ophthalmoplegia, abdominal distention, developmental delay.

Hematologic manifestations: Megaloblastic anemiaia

 

Neurological manifestations: Developmental delay/regression and involuntary movements (tremors).

Megaloblastic anemia, growth retardation, glossitis, neural tube defects in offspring.

questions.text: A 10 y/o child from a rural area with a history of inadequate dietary intake is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. The child's growth is within normal limits, but the caregiver expresses concerns about ensuring proper nutrition, especially concerning iodine intake. What is the recommended daily intake (RDA) of iodine for a child aged 10 years?
questions.correct_answer: B. 120 µg/day

questions.text: A 4 y/o child is diagnosed with zinc deficiency and is experiencing growth delays, delayed sexual maturation, and poor wound healing. The child’s diet consists mostly of cereals and plant-based foods with minimal animal protein. What is the recommended treatment for this child’s zinc deficiency?

options.label: A
options.text: 0.5-1.0 mg elemental zinc/kg/day for several weeks

options.label: B
options.text: 2-4 mg elemental zinc/kg/day for several weeks

questions.correct_answer: B. 2-4 mg elemental zinc/kg/day for several weeks

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with symptoms of irritability, poor feeding, and muscle twitching. An ECG shows a prolonged QTc interval, and the infant exhibits Chvostek and Trousseau signs. What is the most appropriate immediate treatment for this infant's symptoms?

options.label: B
options.text: 2 mL/kg of 10% calcium gluconate IV, administered slowly

questions.correct_answer: B. 2 mL/kg of 10% calcium gluconate IV, administered slowly

questions.text: A 6 y/o child presents with irritability, pallor of nail beds, and fatigue. Laboratory tests reveal microcytic, hypochromic red cells, and reduced serum iron levels. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this child's iron deficiency anemia?
questions.correct_answer: B. Oral iron supplementation at 3-6 mg/kg/day.

questions.text: A 5 y/o child with chronic gastrointestinal malabsorption presents with easy bruising and bleeding. Laboratory tests show a prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and elevated levels of PIVKA (protein induced by vitamin K absence). What is the most appropriate long-term treatment for this child with vitamin K deficiency due to malabsorption?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer 1 mg of parenteral vitamin K.

options.label: B
options.text: Administer 2.5-10 mg of parenteral vitamin K.

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate chronic high-dose oral vitamin K therapy.

questions.correct_answer: C. Initiate chronic high-dose oral vitamin K therapy.
questions.explanation:
Sources
  • Green leafy vegetables.
  • Liver
  • Synthesized by intestinal bacteria.

Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA)
  • Newborns and infants: 3 to 5 µg/day
  • Older children: 10 to 30 µg/day

  • Infants with VKDB
  • Administer 1 mg of parenteral vitamin K.
  • Expect PT to decrease within 6 hours and normalize within 24 hours.
  • For Adolescents
  • Administer 2.5-10 mg of parenteral vitamin K for rapid correction.
  • For Severe, Life-Threatening Bleeding
  • Administer fresh-frozen plasma (FFP) infusion to rapidly correct coagulopathy (along with Vitamin K).
  • For Vitamin K Deficiency Due to Malabsorption in Children
  • Chronic administration of high-dose oral vitamin K (2.5 mg twice weekly to 5 mg daily).

questions.text: A 6-month-old premature infant presents with irritability, poor feeding, and unexplained hemolytic anemia. You suspect a vitamin deficiency. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.correct_answer: C. Vitamin E deficiency

questions.text: A 3 y/o child is brought with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. The child's mother mentions that they recently started a new multivitamin supplement. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum calcium and 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this child?

options.label: C
options.text: Aggressive rehydration with normal saline and discontinuation of vitamin D sources.

questions.correct_answer: C. Aggressive rehydration with normal saline and discontinuation of vitamin D sources.

questions.text: A 3 y/o child with a diet primarily consisting of ultra-high-temperature (UHT) milk presents with a history of irritability, leg swelling, and gum bleeding. Laboratory findings show anemia and normal prothrombin time. Despite initial treatment with iron supplements, the child's symptoms persist. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause and the appropriate intervention?

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic iron deficiency; continue iron therapy and consider a different iron formulation

options.label: B
options.text: Scurvy due to Vitamin C deficiency; initiate high-dose Vitamin C therapy

options.label: C
options.text: Vitamin K deficiency due to malabsorption; administer Vitamin K supplementation

options.label: D
options.text: Excessive calcium intake from fortified milk; reduce calcium and monitor levels

questions.correct_answer: B. Scurvy due to Vitamin C deficiency; initiate high-dose Vitamin C therapy
questions.explanation:
Age Group

RDA (mg/day)

0-6 months

40

7-12 months

50

Vitamin C Source:

Citrus fruits/juices, cauliflower and green leafy vegetables, melons, guava.

Vitamin C Deficiency (Scurvy)

Causes:
  • Heat-treated milk or unfortified formula.
  • Diets lacking fruits and vegetables.

Symptoms:
  • Early: Irritability, loss of appetite, fever, pain, leg tenderness.
  • Later: Swelling, pseudoparalysis, subperiosteal hemorrhages, "rosary" beads at the costochondral junction, gum changes, anemia, bleeding, poor healing.

Treatment:

  • Vitamin C 100-200 mg/day (oral or parenteral).
  • Improvement within a week; continue for 3 months.

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant is brought with c/o irritability, vomiting, and frequent seizures. The mother reports that the infant’s diet consists primarily of formula milk, with minimal introduction of solid foods. O/E, the infant appears listless and has an abnormal EEG pattern. Considering these clinical findings, which of the following deficiencies is most likely responsible for the symptoms described?
questions.correct_answer: B. Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine)
questions.explanation:
Vitamin

RDA

Dietary Sources

Pyridoxine (B6)

0.1-0.3 mg/day

Banana, wheat germ, rice, sunflower seeds, fish, poultry.

Riboflavin (B2)

0.3-0.4mg/day

Milk, green leafy vegetables, sprouts, legumes, meat

Vitamin Deficiencies

 

Pyridoxine (B6) deficiency

Riboflavin (B2) deficiency

Cause
  • High protein intake.
  • Certain medications (eg. Isoniazid)
  • Oral contraceptives.
  • Dialysis.
  • Malnutrition
  • Malabsorption
  • Certain medications
  • Phototherapy

Clinical features:

Infants: Irritability, seizures, vomiting, failure to thrive.

Adults: Peripheral neuritis, cheilosis, glossitis, seborrheic dermatitis, anemia.

Dependency Syndromes: Pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy, Vitamin B6-responsive anemia.

Cheilosis, glossitis, keratitis, conjunctivitis, seborrheic dermatitis, anemia, photophobia. (Option A)

Diagnosis:

Low AST/ALT, high urinary xanthurenic acid, EEG response to pyridoxine.

Clinical response to supplementation, EGR (Erythrocyte Glutathione Reductase) activity test, low urinary riboflavin.

Treatment:

Convulsions: 100 mg pyridoxine IM/IV, then oral intake.

Dependency: 2-10 mg IM or 10-100 mg orally daily.

Oral riboflavin 3-10 mg/day, balanced diet including dairy products

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought in for a routine check-up. The mother has been exclusively breastfeeding and is now concerned about the appropriate time to introduce solid foods. What is the recommended action?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue exclusive breastfeeding until the baby is 9 months old.

options.label: B
options.text: Introduce complementary foods along with breastfeeding.

options.label: C
options.text: Switch entirely to solid foods and stop breastfeeding.

options.label: D
options.text: Start formula feeding and delay introducing solid foods until 7 months.

questions.correct_answer: B. Introduce complementary foods along with breastfeeding.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of poor vision during nighttime and dryness of the eyes. On physical examination, you observe Bitot's spots on the conjunctiva. There is concern about vitamin A deficiency. What is the most appropriate WHO grading of vitamin A deficiency and treatment plan for this child?

options.label: A
options.text: X1B ; 300,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and D7

options.label: B
options.text: X3B ; 100,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and D21

options.label: C
options.text: X1B ; 200,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and D28

options.label: D
options.text: X3B ; 400,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and D14

questions.correct_answer: C. X1B ; 200,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and D28
questions.explanation:
WHO Grading of eye signs of vitamin A deficiency (VAD) in children

Grade

Eye Sign

XN

Night blindness

X1A

Conjunctival xerosis

X1B

Bitot's spots

X2

Corneal xerosis

X3A

Corneal ulcer covering less than 1/3 of the cornea

X3B

Corneal ulcer covering at least 1/3 of the cornea (Option B & D ruled out)

XS

Corneal scarring

Age Group

Treatment

Under 6 months

50,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and 4 weeks later

6 to 12 months

100,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and 4 weeks later

Over 1 year

200,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and 4 weeks later (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: During a visit, the paediatrician discusses vitamin A prophylaxis and dietary sources with the parents of a 2-year-old child. Which of the following statements is correct according to the National Vitamin A Prophylaxis Programme (India) ?

options.label: A
options.text: The first dose is 200,000 IU at 9 months, followed by 100,000 IU every 6 months up to age 5.

options.label: B
options.text: The first dose is 100,000 IU at 9 months, followed by 200,000 IU at 16–18 months, and then every 6 months up to age 5.

options.label: C
options.text: The first dose is 100,000 IU at 6 months, followed by 200,000 IU every year until 5 years of age.

options.label: D
options.text: The RDA of vitamin A for a 2-year-old child is 800–1000 µg/day, and fortified oils are the only acceptable dietary source.

questions.correct_answer: B. The first dose is 100,000 IU at 9 months, followed by 200,000 IU at 16–18 months, and then every 6 months up to age 5.
questions.explanation:
National Vitamin A Prophylaxis Program by the National Health Mission (NHM) of India

Age

Dosage

Additional Context

9 months

100,000 IU

Given along with measles immunization.

16-18 months

200,000 IU

Given with a DPT booster.

Every 6 months

200,000 IU

Up to the age of 5 years.

Total Doses: 9 mega doses from 9 months to 5 years.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE based on the provided information?

options.label: A
options.text: Fore milk satisfies the thirst of the baby.

options.label: B
options.text: Hind milk satisfies the hunger of the baby.

options.label: C
options.text: Preterm breast milk has a higher lactose content than full-term breast milk.

options.label: D
options.text: Preterm breast milk has higher immunoglobulins and protein content.

questions.correct_answer: C. Preterm breast milk has a higher lactose content than full-term breast milk.
questions.explanation:
Factor

Milk Type

Characteristics

Depending on Gestational Age

Fore Milk
  • At the beginning of a feed.
  • It's more thin and watery.
  • High in proteins, sugar, vitamins, and minerals.
  • Satisfies mainly the thirst of the baby. (Option A ruled out)

Hind Milk
  • Produced after the initial release of milk (foremilk).
  • Thicker and calorie-dense.
  • Richer in fat, providing more energy.
  • Satisfies the hunger of the baby. (Option B ruled out)
  • For optimal growth, a neonate requires both foremilk and hindmilk. Therefore, it is important for the baby to fully empty one breast before switching to the other.

Depending on Each Feeding Session

Preterm Breast Milk
  • Richer in Sodium, Immunoglobulins, Proteins, Iron, and Calories. (Mnemonic- S I P For Intelligent CNS) (Option D ruled out)
  • Lesser lactose compared to full-term breast milk

questions.text: Match the following: 1. Colostrum a. Higher in fat and sugar content 2. Transitional Milk b. Higher lactose 3. Mature Milk c. High in antibodies, low in lactose
questions.explanation:
Milk Type

Time of Production

Appearance

Quantity

Key Components

Colostrum

Initial 3-4 days after delivery

Yellow and thick

Small
  • High in antibodies, immune-competent cells, vitamins A, D, E, and K.
  • Rich in immunoglobulins and proteins.
  • Low in lactose.

Transitional Milk

From 3-4 days until two weeks

Thinner than colostrum

Moderate
  • Decreased immunoglobulins and proteins.
  • Increased fat and sugar.

Mature Milk

Follows transitional milk

Thinner and watery

Variable
  • Consistent in nutrient composition
  • Balanced in nutrients essential for growth
  • Higher lactose content.

questions.text: A new mother asks her pediatrician how breast milk's components benefit her baby’s health. Which of the following pairs best describes a protective substance in breast milk and a disease it helps prevent?
questions.correct_answer: D. Bifidus factor; NEC
questions.explanation: Mnemonic: Teach for PLAB

questions.text: A preterm infant is being fed breast milk. Which of the following components is likely to be higher in the breast milk of a mother who delivered prematurely?
questions.correct_answer: C. Protein
questions.explanation:
Breastmilk Composition

Colostrum

The initial, thick, yellow milk is produced during the first 3-4 days after birth. Rich in antibodies (particularly secretory IgA), immune cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K. This early milk provides crucial protection and immunity for the newborn.

Transitional milk

Follows colostrum, appearing from days 3-4 to about two weeks postpartum. A gradual reduction in immunoglobulins and proteins, while fat and sugar levels increase. This shift meets the infant's increasing energy requirements.

Mature milk

Established after the transitional phase. Thinner and more diluted than earlier milk stages, but continues to offer essential nutrients for the baby’s growth.

Carbohydrates - Lactose, Galactose
  • Lactose: The main sugar in breast milk, which helps with calcium absorption and encourages the growth of beneficial gut bacteria.
  • Galactose: Contributes to the development of brain tissue and nerve cell membranes.

Proteins
  • Whey proteins (like lactalbumin and lactoglobulin) - easily digestible.
  • Taurine and cysteine- are important for brain development.

Fats

One of the main energy sources in breast milk, with the composition influenced by the mother’s diet. DHA and ARA are essential for the development of the brain and vision.

Vitamins and minerals

Provides necessary vitamins and minerals in forms that are easily absorbed by the infant.

Note: Vitamin D may be present in low amounts; supplementation might be recommended.

Water and electrolytes

Comprises around 88% water, which typically eliminates the need for additional fluids. The minimal concentration of minerals reduces stress on the baby’s kidneys.

Immunological components

Secretory IgA offers protection against infections. Includes macrophages, lymphocytes, lactoferrin, and lysozyme, which help fight off pathogens.

Growth factors, enzymes, and hormones
  • Epidermal Growth Factor (EGF) supports gut health.
  • Enzymes like lipases, aid in fat digestion.
  • Hormones help regulate appetite and metabolism.

questions.text: A healthcare provider is educating a group of expectant mothers about situations where breastfeeding might not be recommended. Which of the following maternal conditions would most likely contraindicate breastfeeding?

options.label: A
options.text: History of mastitis with successful treatment during pregnancy.

options.label: B
options.text: Active varicella-zoster infection with lesions on the breast.

options.label: C
options.text: Use of a low-dose, progestin-only contraceptive pill.

options.label: D
options.text: Mildly elevated blood pressure controlled with medication.

questions.correct_answer: B. Active varicella-zoster infection with lesions on the breast.
questions.explanation:
Breastfeeding Contraindications

Maternal Contraindications

Infectious Diseases:

  

Active Tuberculosis

Mothers with active tuberculosis should delay breastfeeding until they have completed at least two weeks of appropriate treatment to reduce the risk of transmission.

Active Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Lesions on the Breast:

Breastfeeding is contraindicated if a mother has active herpetic lesions on her breast to prevent transmission to the infant.

Varicella-Zoster Infection

If the mother has active chickenpox lesions, breastfeeding should be avoided to prevent direct contact between the lesions and the infant. The infant should also receive appropriate immunoglobulin. (Option B)

Medications and Treatments:

Chemotherapy, Radiopharmaceuticals and Certain Medications
  • Breastfeeding is usually contraindicated during maternal treatment with chemotherapy or radiopharmaceuticals due to the potential harm to the infant.
  • Specific medications, such as some anticoagulants, anti-tuberculosis drugs, and anticonvulsants, may require mothers to avoid breastfeeding.

Substance Use: Alcohol and Smoking
  • While not a strict contraindication, alcohol consumption should be limited to less than 0.5g/kg/day.
  • Cigarette smoking is strongly discouraged.

Maternal Health Conditions:

  • Severe Illness or Surgery
  • Breast Conditions
  • Maternal issues like mastitis or breast engorgement may complicate breastfeeding and require temporary cessation but are not absolute contraindications.

Fetal Contraindications

Metabolic Disorders: Galactosemia

Infants with galactosemia, a condition where they cannot process galactose, should not be breastfed. Instead, they require specialized formulas.

Anatomical Challenges: Oral or Facial Anomalies

Conditions like cleft palate that affect the infant's ability to suckle may necessitate alternative feeding methods.

Prematurity or Low Birth Weight: Support Needs

Premature or low-birth-weight infants may initially require supplemental feeding methods until they can effectively breastfeed.

questions.text: A new mother visits the clinic concerned that her baby might not be latching on correctly during breastfeeding. She describes that feeding sessions are painful, and her baby seems unsettled afterward. Which of the following observations indicates a poor attachment?

options.label: A
options.text: The baby's mouth is wide open, covering most of the areola.

options.label: B
options.text: The baby's chin is deeply pressing against the breast, with the lower lip flanged outward.

options.label: C
options.text: The mother is leaning towards the baby to help them latch onto the breast.

options.label: D
options.text: The baby’s cheeks are rounded, and swallowing sounds are audible

questions.correct_answer: C. The mother is leaning towards the baby to help them latch onto the breast.

questions.text: A new mother is struggling with milk production and asks what she can do to increase her breast milk supply. Which of the following strategies would be most effective?

options.label: A
options.text: Use a pacifier to soothe the baby between feeds.

options.label: B
options.text: Encourage early and frequent breastfeeding, including night feeds.

options.label: C
options.text: Skip night feeds to ensure the mother gets more rest.

options.label: D
options.text: Offer formula supplements to ensure the baby is getting enough nutrition.

questions.correct_answer: B. Encourage early and frequent breastfeeding, including night feeds.
questions.explanation:
Storage of Expressed Breast Milk

Condition

Safe storage upto

Temperature

Room Temperature

6-8 hours

25 °C

Refrigeration

24 hours

2-8 °C

Freezing

3-6 months

-20 °C

Thawing

Once thawed, used within 24 hours

Under running water
